moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nf6 3. Nf3 e6 4. Nbd2 Nh: New for my standards. I retire the B on g3, so if NxB I get the open h column. Now I'll get quicker developement.
moves.8. Bb5 Bd7: This is the correct answer. If Bb7, Qa4, and if Qd7, Ne5, winning a piece with a much better position.
moves.9. Ba6: Better was BxN, followed by Ne5.
moves.9... f6: ...now Ne5 is impossible, but he opened a line for my Q.
moves.10. Nh4 Ne7: Correctly, defending against Nxg6 after Qh5+.
moves.11. f5: One way or another, I have to break in. I think this is an accurate sacrifice.
moves.11... exf5 12. Qe2: Cramping black's position even more and putting pressure on the open column.
moves.12... Bc8 13. Bb5+ Bd7: I see that there will be no way of getting rid of this B play, so...
moves.14. a4 g6: He streghten f4, now that his B is neutralized, but I was already thinking in a sac Nxf4, and if gxN... Qh5 is not mate unless I have a rook on e1. This is two moves away.
moves.15. O-O c6 16. Nxf5: If BxN, Bxc6+... not sure it would have won, but it looked sacrying enough. And if gxN, Qh5+, Ng6, Re1+, Be7... and nothing happens! Finally, if black plays carelessly, Nd6#.
moves.16... gxf5 17. Rfe1: Now Qh5 is a mate threat.
moves.20... Bd6 21. gxf5 Kg7: Can I win back the piece or not? Very hard for me to tell! Maybe Kh1 or Re3, with a column on the g column wolud have been a good way to sum up against black, but now Nf4 is a serious threat, so...
...and black resigned because the mate is unstoppable.
